In what topography is Houston located?
How is the vegetation of the area classified?
What kind of weather event is a recurring problem for Houston?

context: According to the United States Census Bureau, the city has a total area of <a0_0><b5_0>656.3 square miles<b5_0/><a0_0/> (1,700 km2); this comprises 634.0 square miles (1,642 km2) of land and <a1_0><b6_0>22.3 square miles<b6_0/><a1_0/> (58 km2) of water. The Piney Woods is north of Houston. Most of Houston is located on the <a2_0><b7_0>gulf coastal plain<b7_0/><a2_0/>, and its vegetation is classified as <a3_0><b8_0>temperate grassland and forest<b8_0/><a3_0/>. Much of the city was built on forested land, marshes, swamp, or prairie which resembles the Deep South, and are all still visible in surrounding areas. Flatness of the local terrain, when combined with urban sprawl, has made <a4_0><b9_0>flooding<b9_0/><a4_0/> a recurring problem for the city. Downtown stands about 50 feet (15 m) above sea level, and the highest point in far northwest Houston is about 125 feet (38 m) in elevation. The city once relied on groundwater for its needs, but land subsidence forced the city to turn to ground-level water sources such as Lake Houston, Lake Conroe and Lake Livingston. The city owns surface water rights for 1.20 billion gallons of water a day in addition to 150 million gallons a day worth of groundwater.
